If you add opposing constraints on a view, the constraint lines become squiggly like a spring to indicate the opposing forces, as shown in video 2. The effect is most visible when the view size is set to or in which case the view is centered between the constraints. If you instead want the view to stretch its size to meet the constraints, switch the size to match constraints; or if you want to keep the current size but move the view so that it is not centered, adjust the constraint bias
